For people who are making immersive sims, you can create variability in Lotke-Volterra systems by modulating these rates of return. By allowing them this leeway, along with a genetic algorithm, it gives populations under evolutionary pressure opportunities to reach a new local maxima. Something to think on.

We can also find a function thru this
We want rate of increase of happiness to be decreasing therefore
d2H/dt^2 to be negative
Hence we want dH/dt to be a decreasing function which shouls be integrable for us to be able to find H as a function of time
Say dH/dt = e^(-x)
So H would be
H = -e^(-x) + c
Since we want it to start from (0,0)
So c= 1
H = -e^(-x) + 1
Is also a viable simulation.

When I was searching for what course to enrol in, I entered a lecture promoting economics on an open day, where the professor was asking for volunteers who will get free(!) sweets. Of course, he got lots of volunteers.

The experiment was diminishing marginal utility. 3 eaters, three scorers. He gave each eater a share size bag of Mars bars and made them eat them one after the other, and give the happiness rating from eating that Mars bar to the scorer. Everyone shared the same graph of happiness representation besides one volunteer scorer who drew a phallic shaped line which didn’t match with the scores whatsoever.

I now have a degree in Economics. Thanks Dr. Kinsella.

Cutting wood leaves mangos on the ground. So assuming that you know how many mangos and wood you're going to get today. Getting mangos or wood first is slower because of the time you must take to walk past a tree to get the next mango. The best way would be, tree, mango, tree, mango, or mango, tree, mango, tree. Preferably "mango, tree" not to risk mangos rolling further. It's simple but for when there are 2 mangos on a tree just go, mango, mango, tree, to still avoid trees dropping mangos and mangos rolling further. This might sound like a small time-save but it might add one or two mangos worth of collection in a single day. I think an interesting strategy would have been to assign a happiness value that is based on overall happiness based on a set amount of time, and an immediate happiness. So for example you could assign an immediate happiness, let's say(100) happiness for getting a mango. The blob eats the mango right away so therefore it provides immediate happiness. The downfall is that eventually he will need more mangos, and staying warm is also another problem. Collecting more than one mango like you described can have a logarithmic function attached to it in the short term but the blob should be rewarded with extra happiness for its efforts in the long term. With wood you could assign 0 happiness for collecting wood with the idea that over time the blob will understand eventually that to survive you need wood. And at some point the collection of wood will obtain its own happiness value for the blob.

Would’ve been cool to see it expanded to value wood differently, as in say it needed to get 1 wood every 2 days to burn to stay warm and survive, so the happiness value for wood would be higher on the day when it’s previous wood it collected 2 days ago ran out. However it could also stockpile it, and say if it chopped a tree down, it got both the wood, AND the mangoes from it, but the tree wouldn’t grow back for say 3 days. And so it had to figure out an optimal strategy to farm food from the trees, while also being selective about when and how many trees to cut down, knowing it needed wood to survive, but also knowing it could stockpile the wood, while also knowing the less trees it leaves in the Forrest, the less mangoes it has to pick the next day until the trees it had chopped down regrow. And then run it for like a “month” of its time and see what it’s 1 week routine was to give it the highest happiness score while balancing what it takes from the Forrest. Maybe make 1 tree worth 2 wood but you need 1.5 wood per day to burn to stay alive. Then also maybe adding in the possibility to harvest mangoes and rather than eat them, plant the seed from it and give it a 50% chance of growing into a tree in 2 days.

This is classic microeconomics, I had that at university, and I always had soooooooooooo many criticisms to this model I don't even know where to start, but I'd be so interested in trying to make an alternative "communalist behavior" model if you're interested. Anyway here is my number one criticism of microeconomics...
If we're taking only 2 choices they need to represent a dualistic absolute that leaves nothing missing. And that is impossible, right? Like... the best I can do is having the blob chose between production and leisure where production represents "orderly and structured products of desire" and leisure represents "disorderly and schizophrenic products of desire".
There's always this "irrational behavior" that the models have a big trouble envisioning but they might seem more evident if we try to create models of behavior we can't really experience in the real life. Could you create an anarchist model? Something where blobs end up having to chose between their own happiness and well-being of their ecosystem in a direct democracy scenario?

i would be curious to add rain. like if rain is random & means you cant collect wood, would its behavior skew in anticipation? logically it should favor wood initially, which would also produce a surplus to what it wants if its anticipating not being able to collect wood the next day. on the model you showed here this would seem counter intuitive, so i guess it really depends if the model is factoring multiple days or just the one.

as for neighbor trading, i would expect the only gain is time. mangos are faster than wood, so trading should be faster than mangos. but to gain wood from a trade means the neighbor has to gain mangos, which means collecting mangos. but the inverse would be collecting wood to trade for mangos, when collecting mangos is faster. if they place the highest value on mangos, its possible they would collect all the mangos & then use spare time to collect wood just for trading. but if noone wants wood, it doesnt work. alternatively if the neighbor values wood more, he might reserve some time for collecting mangos just to trade. but it all depends on the exchange rate & differing valuations.

Primer is slowly turning from a pseudo Evolutionary Psychology channel into an Austrian Economics channel.

Primer, these simulations are a bit absurd since you can tweak them in order to get the conclusions you want. You even accept this in one of the evolutionary videos. Using simulations to understand (and explain) these concepts is just bad epistemology as you asume certain things that are not true (or are, at least very limited). So you're basically sending any message you want and disguising it as science through cute animations and pseudoscientific non-empiric methods. You see, the problem of trying to learn things about real life phenomena based on simulations is that you end up learning things about your simulation, which is of course limited by your arbitrary assumptions. This process of learning about your arbitrary assumptions is what I like to call "Epistemological Onanism" and is sometimes useful, but I don't think you are not presenting this in an honest way. Viewers probably extrapolate and think that what you are saying is a good model for reality (which is not). This makes your message as dangerous as that of any shaman.

In the Supply and Demand video you trick the viewers by using rockets as something to exchange, rather than blob-food, for example. The result of this is a model that differs from most market interactions that happen throughout the planet every day, as these more often include 'needs' and not 'wants'. People can go without rocket toys, but they can't go without food or water or housing. As a result of this, those who offer these goods and services often have far more bargaining power than those who demand these goods and services. Ignoring this is disingenuous. You also ignore the fact that the scale of those who offer goods and services is often far bigger than that of those who demand good and services and so, again, their bargaining power is far larger. Walmart is far bigger than any individual who buys in Walmart. If 1000 people go individually to buy one apple each at a shop, they will all get a certain price X, but if restaurant goes to buy 1000 apples, it will get a lover price Y (Y<X). You seem to choose to ignore these things in order to deceive your viewers.

[Note that the individuals mentioned in this example will also keep the doctor away if they repeat this every day]

In this video you present the Law of Marginal Utility. It is not surprising that you explain this economic concept using melons and not wood as this Law of Marginal Utility might not work with this other resource. If you use the wood to build a house, the first wooden boards will be used to build the walls and so will have very low utility as they will fail at protecting you from the rain and snow. However, the more wooden boards you add, the more each wooden board will contribute to protecting you from the rain and snow. The last wooden boards will be used for the roof and so each will add the maximum marginal utility. Your choice to use melons as an example to explain this law also causes a very limited interpretation of it's implications. If instead of lemons we take a certain service like watching Netflix episodes we soon realize that the fact that the marginal returns decrease does not result in limiting the use of this service but rather the oposite, one might try to archive the same level of utility as they did in the first episodes by watching more and more episodes. This explains compulsive and addictive behaviour and why people binge-watch full seasons of tv shows in Netflix, and end up feeling even more empty than when they started. We see this behaviour in the compulsive and addictive use of social media too.

I guess that in the next video you will try to convince us of how Free Market, in combination with this Law of Marginal Utility, results in the utility maximization of both the blue blob and yellow blob. However, lets stop and consider that there where many green blobs (maybe black blobs if we want to be realistic) that do not own any forest (means of production) to start with, but still have to eat melons in order to keep living. Considering all the above, the blue and yellow blobs can exploit the green blobs making them work for a very low melon-salary, in order to extract the maximum plus-value from them. The green blobs will be therefore coerced into generating wealth for the other two blobs, and will have no freedom to refuse to do, as they need these melons to prevent themselves from dying. The blue (Jeff Bezos) and yellow (Warren Buffet) balls would then become addicted to hoarding melons and wood because they would need more and more units of woods and melons in order to get the same kick/high of utility they got with the first melons and woods. This would be a far more realistic model.

I know this is just meant to be illustrative, and I enjoy your simulation videos greatly, but I always have a problem with these game-theory ecology-type stuff. They assume people always make rational, fully informed, and efficient choices; they don't. There could be numerous reasons, besides happiness, resource availability, and time, to explain why Blob collects a certain amount of resources. Blob could lack pertinent information. Blob could be sick. Blob could just be feeling lazy today. Blob could be visiting friends or attending a religious or cultural observation instead of foraging. Blob could decide, on a whim, to forage for herbs, instead etc. I don't think it's possible to create a set of formulae that describes foraging patterns in some pristine contextless environment. Various evolutionary anthropologists spend their time doing this and it really adds nothing to the discipline. People aren't machines, we don't think like your (or other people's) models.

@Primer any chance of revisiting and elaborating on the evolution of aggression to explore conditions under which (in moderation) it's in fact adaptive?

I think the following model would do the trick:
- start with same premise of blobs foraging for pellets each day
- pellets provide 3 types of nutrients: salts, lipids (fats), and carbs (sugars)
- each day the blob's "metabolizes" a random amount (5-20%) of their store of each nutrient
- whenever a blob's levels of any nutrient falls below say 33%, it becomes "ravenous" for that resource and prioritizes pellets of the appropriate color
- any level dropping to zero causes immediate death due to malnutrition
- red pellets are high in salt, green high in lipds, blue high in carbs, and white is balanced
- if a blob eats a "high value" pellet, its stock of just that nutrient rises 25%
- a white pellet will increase each nutrient level by 15%

Now run 2 versions of the simulation:
a) blobs are all doves, and if both go for the same pellet, will split it 50-50 regardless of its type
b) blobs usually behave like doves, but ravenous ones turn into hawks. Doves going for the same resource will back down and seek another next pellet, while competing hawks will result in mutual injury.

I pulled the numbers out of my hat so they may need to be tweaked, but I suspect there are circumstances under which (b) thrives better than (a) due to more efficient allocation of specialized resources matching the unique needs of the blob at that moment in time. In other words, if blobs selectively activate aggression only when their needs match the resource, the overall likelihood of survival actually rises.

This video is really interesting, showing those things in terms of mathematics. I ended up thinking about the next topic, trading. With the same variables on each side (i.e. same gathering speed, availability of resources) trade should be disadvantageous as foraging both resources equally results in highest total production (as you gather more wood or food the distance to the next source of your resource increases), and focusing on one resource means your total production is less AND you might end up needing to purchase (introducing loss factors such as the seller wanting to profit, possible energy/time spent trading, etc.). On the other hand, trade should be beneficial if specialization is introduced in some way, whether innate (faster wood cutting speed, for example) or learned (after every return home with mangoes you can carry one more). I'm excited to see what the next video shows us.

Okay but the happiness charts of wood and mangoes wouldn't be the same. If you have to use everything, too many mangoes can make you unhappy while more wood just means more heat. I'd be interested in seeing the bell curve for the apples and the diminishing returns for the wood.

Alternatively, if you do use diminishing returns for the apples and assume you don't have to eat them all...mangoes go bad eventually, so that time collecting those that went bad was meaningless. Meanwhile, wood lasts much longer and won't go bad, so that time collecting the wood can be recouped later when you have enough wood to not spend time collecting it. This can come in handy if running low on food or if you want to collect a new resource or take time to rest. In this case the diminishing returns on mangoes would flatten out eventually, while the diminishing returns on wood would not, and the wood would have a steeper slope as those extra logs hold more value and therefore happiness.

You can use Lagrange`s multipliers method to calculate the optimal number of mangoes and wood to be collected. Happines H(m, w) is a certain function of number of mangoes and pieces of wood, and it needs to be maximized. Also there is a constraint, f(m, w) = 0, where f is a function that relates the number of mangoes and the number of pieces of wood the blob collects. So then, according to Lagrange, dH/dm = L df/dm and dH/dw = L df/dw, where L is some constant. Function f is not continuous, but it can be made continuous by smoothing it, for example by using a Fourier series.

This doesn't feel right. Instead of simulation this seemed more like a number comperator or clock. The simplicity of the example, killed the real world practice or application of the example. The math is right, but the rest feels innacurate, due to the shortage of context and data. Aka you would never get 9 mango, when you can eat only 2, unless you would sold it.

If you would add the concept of carpentry to a database, with items, it would change everything. You can eat two mango, as it gives happiness, but if you eat only 1 you might be able to make 2 items. Which could make you richer, faster or better -> prosper. But also, surplus mango could be sold, and gold gets you items. (aka id|desc|value|need|time) Which would work great with kids, because it turns everything upside down.

In irl --> This would compare short term and long term happiness, behaviour. If you are sad, you want your happiness boosted or the least lost. You are in pain, you don't want any more. If you are weak, you want to conserve. You want to rest.
Bad times goes with less exhausting lifestyle, conserving, putting away, preparing, healing, always trying to be at max.. In good times you exhaust yourself to reach the maximum potency of your capabilities.

I like your work, the video is good too. Don't misunderstand, it was brilliant. But I have no "why" to the math and the example. Real life doesn't work by math, and you don't need simulation for math, as they rarely collide and it would be very forced to make it the same. There are applications for math in real life. From bridges to economy, to social behaviour. But this didn't felt like any of it. It felt like the Blub was trying to prove the math, instead of himself.

This explains how people value money in different ways. Some decide to spend it on stuff that makes them temporarily happy, so they don't value it as much, and some decide to spend it on helping others and doing charity, so they value it a lot more. Money is the same, but your decisions change its value, the way you decide to use it determines how valuable it is for you. Also, it depends on your conditions and circumstances (whether you actually NEED more money or just WANT more of it)

One point here, not everything is of diminishing marginal utility. Some resources do something else entirely. For example, the difference between having 10/10 windows in your house actually exist and 9/10 is MUCH greater than the difference between having 9/10 and 8/10. A massive increase in marginal utility. And having additional windows you cannot do anything with provides very little or no marginal utility.

Why not project the "production possibilities curve" onto the surface you constructed at 6:12? The diminishing returns for mango collection and stock should change directions because having a bountiful amount of food means you have to collect less often and you will be secure if for some reason you can't or don't want to collect mangoes. It should diminish slowly, then provide a huge boost after a certain threshold. Seeing you have 10 mangoes will make you happy, seeing you have too many mangoes to easily count will make you very happy. The only factor which changes that is rotting resources. IF the mangoes go bad or the wood starts diminishing, happiness will decrease with large amounts of resources because of the knowledge of expiration. In that case, having good preservation solutions will help return the happiness value of having bountiful amounts of food.

Another way of explaining why the last outcome did not change that much front the beginning is because of the different ways a production possibility graph moves. An increase of resources does not increase shift the Production Possibilities Graph unless output is not at a maximum(in this case it wasn’t so it was shifted). There are a couple ways to shift the curve to the right: 1) Advanced Technology(Give blob an Axe to increase wood chopping ability) 2) More training to increase efficiency 3) Increase in Labor Force.

Side Note: You mentioned next time that you were going to add a second blob to trade with and stuff. It would be cool if you could make the blobs specialized. So like one blob has an axe while the other one is good at picking fruit, and then allow them to trade to see where the optimal amount of goods for each blob to get the most resources.

Whole concept is nonsense.  The reason it is nonsense is because the time window is arbitrary, the 'value' of a mango goes down or does not go down depending upon the time-frame you are using the resource in.  If we are thinking 'number of mangoes per week' rather than 'number of mangoes per day', we do not see the whole downward curve in 'value'.  But we can even then upscale the time-frame to months, years, decades, centuries and so on.
